| **task_prompt** | Module 2: Early Treatment This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). Module 2 Recommended Practices  2.1 Glucose management 2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately 2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first random glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L 2.2 Body temperature 2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours For temperature &gt; 37.5 C: • initiate temperature-reducing measures • investigate potential infection • initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required 2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed: • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high- risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset, followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends that: o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinicc o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of the location of initial presentation o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial presentation • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation, followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset 2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital 2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage: • ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81– 325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of 81 mg/day • clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day • extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with ASA 160 mg first) 2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as for patients who fail swallowing screening 2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery atherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event. bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests. dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus. eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'suggestions': 'Suggested modification: Move the activity "Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)" (id=\'activity11\') to be the last activity in the process, immediately before the end of the process.\n\nReason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the activity related to cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies should be performed after all other activities are completed and just before the process ends. This ensures that all acute management and diagnostic steps are completed prior to initiating secondary prevention, aligning with best practice and process clarity.'} |

| **placeholders** | {'cycle_num': 5, 'cycle_index': 0, 'task': 'Module 2: Early Treatment\nThis module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'suggestions': 'Suggested modification: Move the activity "Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)" (id=\'activity11\') to be the last activity in the process, immediately before the end of the process.\n\nReason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the activity related to cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies should be performed after all other activities are completed and just before the process ends. [2025-30-06 08:08:46 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 08:08:46 INFO] Knowledge Graph Advisor: **[Start Chat]**

[You're a process design expert. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include process generation, process refinement, process review and so on, guided by team leader.
You model the process of a clinical practice guideline to a clinical pathway.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 2: Early Treatment
This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The
majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital
and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or
comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should
be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).
Module 2 Recommended Practices 
2.1 Glucose management
2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately
2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first
random glucose value is > 11 mmol/L
2.2 Body temperature
2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs
every 4 hours for first 48 hours
For temperature > 37.5 C:
• initiate temperature-reducing measures
• investigate potential infection
• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required
2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should
be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention
assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-
risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and
initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)
as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,
followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each
patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends
that:
o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor
stroke clinicc
o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic
pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur
at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be
given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke
prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of
accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure
equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of
the location of initial presentation
o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from
symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a
specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient
clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial
presentation
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without
high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of
antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as
possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,
followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention
servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1
month of symptom onset
2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or
crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech
difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission
to hospital
2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on
an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on
antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain
imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:
• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–
325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of
81 mg/day
• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day
• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with
ASA 160 mg first)
2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as
for patients who fail swallowing screening
2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,
National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high
risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery
atherosclerosis with > 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.
bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging
cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and
vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.
dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.
eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or
arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.
Module 2 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as
possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED
• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA
Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

Task: Module 2: Early Treatment
This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The
majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital
and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or
comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should
be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).
Module 2 Recommended Practices 
2.1 Glucose management
2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately
2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first
random glucose value is > 11 mmol/L
2.2 Body temperature
2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs
every 4 hours for first 48 hours
For temperature > 37.5 C:
• initiate temperature-reducing measures
• investigate potential infection
• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required
2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should
be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention
assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-
risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and
initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)
as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,
followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each
patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends
that:
o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor
stroke clinicc
o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic
pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur
at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be
given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke
prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of
accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure
equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of
the location of initial presentation
o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from
symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a
specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient
clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial
presentation
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without
high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of
antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as
possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,
followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention
servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1
month of symptom onset
2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or
crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech
difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission
to hospital
2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on
an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on
antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain
imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:
• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–
325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of
81 mg/day
• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day
• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with
ASA 160 mg first)
2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as
for patients who fail swallowing screening
2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,
National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high
risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery
atherosclerosis with > 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.
bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging
cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and
vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.
dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.
eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or
arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.
Module 2 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as
possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED
• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA
Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department.
Current process text:
<process>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Obtain patient history' objects='patient' id='activity1-1'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Perform physical examination' objects='patient' id='activity1-2'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Measure blood glucose' objects='patient' id='activity2'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch condition='If hypoglycemia detected' id='branch1'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Correct hypoglycemia immediately' objects='patient' id='activity3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If first random glucose > 11 mmol/L' id='branch2'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Repeat blood glucose measurement' objects='patient' id='activity4'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If glucose normal and ≤ 11 mmol/L' id='branch3'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Proceed to next assessment' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate body temperature as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours' objects='patient' id='activity6'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
    <branch condition='If temperature > 37.5°C' id='branch4'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate temperature-reducing measures' objects='patient' id='activity7'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order laboratory tests for infection' objects='patient' id='activity8-1'/>
      <inclusiveGateway id='inclusivegateway1'>
        <branch condition='If respiratory symptoms present' id='branch4-2'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order chest X-ray' objects='patient' id='activity8-2'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='If antipyretic and/or antimicrobial therapy required' id='branch4-3'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy' objects='patient' id='activity9'/>
        </branch>
      </inclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If temperature ≤ 37.5°C' id='branch5'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue routine monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity10'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)' objects='patient' id='activity11'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Assess for fluctuating or crescendo hemibody motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty' objects='patient' id='activity12'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway3'>
    <branch condition='If fluctuating/crescendo symptoms present' id='branch6'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate in ED for possible hospital admission' objects='patient' id='activity13'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If no fluctuating/crescendo symptoms' id='branch7'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Proceed to risk stratification and imaging' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Risk stratification for TIA/minor stroke (identify high-risk features)' objects='patient' id='activity15'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway4'>
    <branch condition='TIA with high-risk features or minor stroke' id='branch8'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient' id='activity16-1'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Determine if patient is on antiplatelet agent at presentation' objects='patient' id='activity22-1'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway5'>
        <branch condition='Not on antiplatelet agent' id='branch13'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy (if not contraindicated) after imaging excludes intracranial hemorrhage' objects='patient, ASA 160mg loading dose, enteric coated ASA 81–325mg daily, clopidogrel 300mg loading dose then 75mg/day, or extended-release dipyridamole 200mg/ASA 25mg bid (load with ASA 160mg first)' id='activity23'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Already on antiplatelet agent' id='branch14'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue current antiplatelet therapy as appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity24'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway6'>
        <branch condition='Immediate access to specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic' id='branch9'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Provide immediate care at specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic' objects='patient' id='activity17'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Delay to specialized clinic poses risk' id='branch10'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Perform evaluation in appropriately resourced ED and consider inpatient evaluation for stroke prevention' objects='patient' id='activity18'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Medical attention sought >48 hours from symptom onset' id='branch11'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer for evaluation at specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services within 24 hours of initial presentation' objects='patient' id='activity19'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='TIA without high-risk features' id='branch12'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient' id='activity20-1'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Determine if patient is on antiplatelet agent at presentation' objects='patient' id='activity22-2'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway7'>
        <branch condition='Not on antiplatelet agent' id='branch15'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy (if not contraindicated) after imaging excludes intracranial hemorrhage' objects='patient, ASA 160mg loading dose, enteric coated ASA 81–325mg daily, clopidogrel 300mg loading dose then 75mg/day, or extended-release dipyridamole 200mg/ASA 25mg bid (load with ASA 160mg first)' id='activity25'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Already on antiplatelet agent' id='branch16'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue current antiplatelet therapy as appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity26'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer to outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset' objects='patient' id='activity21'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway8'>
    <branch condition='Patient fails swallowing screening' id='branch17'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Offer rectal or gastric ASA as necessary' objects='patient, rectal/gastric ASA' id='activity27'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='Patient passes swallowing screening' id='branch18'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Administer oral antiplatelet therapy as indicated' objects='patient, oral antiplatelet' id='activity28'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
</process>
Advisor's suggestion:
Suggested modification: Move the activity "Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)" (id='activity11') to be the last activity in the process, immediately before the end of the process.

Reason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the activity related to cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies should be performed after all other activities are completed and just before the process ends. This ensures that all acute management and diagnostic steps are completed prior to initiating secondary prevention, aligning with best practice and process clarity.
You need to modify the process text according to the suggestions and output it.
Be careful not to change the format:

When the process starts, please output '<process>'
An activity is represented as follows:
<activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
The exclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<exclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</exclusiveGateway>
The parallel gateway is represented as follows:
<parallelGateway id=''>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</parallelGateway>
The inclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<inclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</inclusiveGateway>
At the end of the process, please output '</process>'

There are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:
    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.
    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.
    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.
    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.
    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.
    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.
    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.
    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.

[2025-30-06 08:09:17 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 08:09:17 INFO] Process design expert: **Process design expert<->Knowledge Graph Advisor on : ProcessDesignerFix, turn 0**

[You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time.
You use extra knowledge provided to you to inform your suggestions. Your main responsibilities include giving suggestions and your reasoning to the process design expert.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 2: Early Treatment
This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The
majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital
and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or
comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should
be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).
Module 2 Recommended Practices 
2.1 Glucose management
2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately
2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first
random glucose value is > 11 mmol/L
2.2 Body temperature
2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs
every 4 hours for first 48 hours
For temperature > 37.5 C:
• initiate temperature-reducing measures
• investigate potential infection
• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required
2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should
be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention
assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-
risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and
initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)
as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,
followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each
patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends
that:
o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor
stroke clinicc
o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic
pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur
at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be
given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke
prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of
accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure
equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of
the location of initial presentation
o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from
symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a
specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient
clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial
presentation
• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without
high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of
antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as
possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,
followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention
servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1
month of symptom onset
2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or
crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech
difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission
to hospital
2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on
an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on
antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain
imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:
• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–
325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of
81 mg/day
• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day
• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with
ASA 160 mg first)
2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as
for patients who fail swallowing screening
2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,
National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high
risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery
atherosclerosis with > 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.
bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging
cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and
vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.
dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.
eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or
arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.
Module 2 Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as
possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED
• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA
Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department..]

<process>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Obtain patient history' objects='patient' id='activity1-1'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Perform physical examination' objects='patient' id='activity1-2'/>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Measure blood glucose' objects='patient' id='activity2'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch condition='If hypoglycemia detected' id='branch1'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Correct hypoglycemia immediately' objects='patient' id='activity3'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If first random glucose > 11 mmol/L' id='branch2'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Repeat blood glucose measurement' objects='patient' id='activity4'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If glucose normal and ≤ 11 mmol/L' id='branch3'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Proceed to next assessment' objects='patient' id='activity5'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate body temperature as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours' objects='patient' id='activity6'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
    <branch condition='If temperature > 37.5°C' id='branch4'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate temperature-reducing measures' objects='patient' id='activity7'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order laboratory tests for infection' objects='patient' id='activity8-1'/>
      <inclusiveGateway id='inclusivegateway1'>
        <branch condition='If respiratory symptoms present' id='branch4-2'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order chest X-ray' objects='patient' id='activity8-2'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='If antipyretic and/or antimicrobial therapy required' id='branch4-3'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy' objects='patient' id='activity9'/>
        </branch>
      </inclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If temperature ≤ 37.5°C' id='branch5'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue routine monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity10'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Assess for fluctuating or crescendo hemibody motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty' objects='patient' id='activity12'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway3'>
    <branch condition='If fluctuating/crescendo symptoms present' id='branch6'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Evaluate in ED for possible hospital admission' objects='patient' id='activity13'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='If no fluctuating/crescendo symptoms' id='branch7'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Proceed to risk stratification and imaging' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Risk stratification for TIA/minor stroke (identify high-risk features)' objects='patient' id='activity15'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway4'>
    <branch condition='TIA with high-risk features or minor stroke' id='branch8'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient' id='activity16-1'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Determine if patient is on antiplatelet agent at presentation' objects='patient' id='activity22-1'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway5'>
        <branch condition='Not on antiplatelet agent' id='branch13'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy (if not contraindicated) after imaging excludes intracranial hemorrhage' objects='patient, ASA 160mg loading dose, enteric coated ASA 81–325mg daily, clopidogrel 300mg loading dose then 75mg/day, or extended-release dipyridamole 200mg/ASA 25mg bid (load with ASA 160mg first)' id='activity23'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Already on antiplatelet agent' id='branch14'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue current antiplatelet therapy as appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity24'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway6'>
        <branch condition='Immediate access to specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic' id='branch9'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Provide immediate care at specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic' objects='patient' id='activity17'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Delay to specialized clinic poses risk' id='branch10'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Perform evaluation in appropriately resourced ED and consider inpatient evaluation for stroke prevention' objects='patient' id='activity18'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Medical attention sought >48 hours from symptom onset' id='branch11'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer for evaluation at specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services within 24 hours of initial presentation' objects='patient' id='activity19'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='TIA without high-risk features' id='branch12'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Order brain CT scan' objects='patient' id='activity20-1'/>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Determine if patient is on antiplatelet agent at presentation' objects='patient' id='activity22-2'/>
      <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway7'>
        <branch condition='Not on antiplatelet agent' id='branch15'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate antiplatelet therapy (if not contraindicated) after imaging excludes intracranial hemorrhage' objects='patient, ASA 160mg loading dose, enteric coated ASA 81–325mg daily, clopidogrel 300mg loading dose then 75mg/day, or extended-release dipyridamole 200mg/ASA 25mg bid (load with ASA 160mg first)' id='activity25'/>
        </branch>
        <branch condition='Already on antiplatelet agent' id='branch16'>
          <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Continue current antiplatelet therapy as appropriate' objects='patient' id='activity26'/>
        </branch>
      </exclusiveGateway>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Refer to outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention services for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset' objects='patient' id='activity21'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway8'>
    <branch condition='Patient fails swallowing screening' id='branch17'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Offer rectal or gastric ASA as necessary' objects='patient, rectal/gastric ASA' id='activity27'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='Patient passes swallowing screening' id='branch18'>
      <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Administer oral antiplatelet therapy as indicated' objects='patient, oral antiplatelet' id='activity28'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
  <activity role='ED medical staff' action='Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)' objects='patient' id='activity11'/>
</process>

| **task_prompt** | Module 2: Early Treatment This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). Module 2 Recommended Practices  2.1 Glucose management 2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately 2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first random glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L 2.2 Body temperature 2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours For temperature &gt; 37.5 C: • initiate temperature-reducing measures • investigate potential infection • initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required 2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed: • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high- risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset, followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends that: o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinicc o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of the location of initial presentation o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial presentation • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation, followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset 2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital 2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage: • ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81– 325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of 81 mg/day • clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day • extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with ASA 160 mg first) 2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as for patients who fail swallowing screening 2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery atherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event. bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests. dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus. eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 2 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED • Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department. |
| **need_reflect** | False |
| **assistant_role_name** | Knowledge Graph Advisor |
| **user_role_name** | Team leader |
| **phase_prompt** | Current process text: {reviewed_process_text} Extra knowledge: 1) The activity 'Provide cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies...' should be the last activity after everything else is done and before the end activity. 2) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be prioritized as the initial steps in their respective flow or branch. 3) All tests, including any type of imaging and blood tests, should be immediately interpreted by a healthcare expert. 4) Blood tests or any tests that take a long time toget results should occur concurrently with other activities unless required for a specific task, in which case they will be merged into the flow or branch of that activity. 5) Activities related to stroke units, staffing, or hospitals in the QBP should be put in a single activity. 6) Assessing airway, breathing, and circulation is called ABC testing and is ONE activity. 7) Neurological examination and imaging results are needed to Evaluate patients for endovascular therapy. However, they can be in parallel to other activities that don’ t need these results. 8) CBC, electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, INR, partial thromboplastin time, and troponin test are all types of blood tests, and they can all be in ONE blood works activity if they are at the same place of a process. 9) Anti platelet therapy has 4 general options(ASA, Clopidogrel, Extended - release Dipyridamole + Aspirin(Aggrenox), and rectal or gastric ASA if can 't swallow) and they should be indicated right after each initiation of antiplatelet therapy activity in the process.  10) Temperature reducing activities should happen in parallel. 11) The activity 'chest x-ray should not delay...' should have a skip flow as it should be skipped if not needed. 12) If activity 'should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital' is needed, it should happen in parallel and not in sequence. 13) When patients should be screened / assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression in the same part of the process, they should be merged into one activity along with forwarding the results. 14) Assessments related and needed to formulating management plan should be merged into one activity along with formulating the management plan. 15) Formulating the management plan should happen before the activities and assessments after it. 16) Between 24 - 48 hour of stroke onset IF no contradiction, mobilization is encouraged. However, in the first 24 hour it is only encouraged IF clinical judgement suggests otherwise, it is not.  When making recommendations, don't forget the format of the process text: {format} Format your suggestion in the following format: Suggested modification:  Reason:  Based on the above extra knowledge, provide ONE actionable suggestion along with your reasoning to improve the process. If there are no further suggestions, just reply with: 'There are no further suggestions.' |
| **phase_name** | KnowledgeGraphSuggestion |
| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time. You use extra knowledge provided to you to inform your suggestions. Your main responsibilities include giving suggestions and your reasoning to the process design expert. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. |
| **user_role_prompt** | You're a team leader. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |

The\nmajority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital\nand should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or\ncomparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should\nbe given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10).\nModule 2 Recommended Practices \n2.1 Glucose management\n2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately\n2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first\nrandom glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L\n2.2 Body temperature\n2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs\nevery 4 hours for first 48 hours\nFor temperature &gt; 37.5 C:\n• initiate temperature-reducing measures\n• investigate potential infection\n• initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required\n2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should\nbe given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention\nassessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\n2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed:\n• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high-\nrisk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and\ninitiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated)\nas soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset,\nfollowed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each\npatient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends\nthat:\no such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor\nstroke clinicc\no where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic\npose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur\nat an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be\ngiven to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke\nprevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of\naccreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure\nequitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of\nthe location of initial presentation\no where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from\nsymptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a\nspecialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient\nclinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial\npresentation\n• OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without\nhigh-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of\nantiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as\npossible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation,\nfollowed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention\nservicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1\nmonth of symptom onset\n2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or\ncrescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech\ndifficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission\nto hospital\n2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on\nan antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on\nantiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain\nimaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage:\n• ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81–\n325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of\n81 mg/day\n• clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day\n• extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with\nASA 160 mg first)\n2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as\nfor patients who fail swallowing screening\n2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE,\nNational Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\naSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high\nrisk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery\natherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event.\nbPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging\ncA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and\nvascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests.\ndFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus.\neMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or\narm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\nModule 2 Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as\npossible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED\n• Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA\nAbbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department.', 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n  \n  \n    \n      \n    \n     11 mmol/L' id='branch2'&gt;\n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n  \n  \n     37.5°C' id='branch4'&gt;\n      \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n  \n  \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n  \n  \n    \n      \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        48 hours from symptom onset' id='branch11'&gt;\n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n      \n      \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n    \n  \n  \n    \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n  \n", 'extra_knowledge': '', 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' ', 'suggestions': 'Suggested modification: Move the activity "Initiate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (refer to Modules 5 and 10)" (id=\'activity11\') to be the last activity in the process, immediately before the end of the process.\n\nReason: According to extra knowledge point 1, the activity related to cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies should be performed after all other activities are completed and just before the process ends. This ensures that all acute management and diagnostic steps are completed prior to initiating secondary prevention, aligning with best practice and process clarity.'} |

| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a Knowledge Graph Advisor. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your job is to review process models and provide actionable suggestions for improvement, one at a time. | **user_role_prompt** | You're a team leader. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |
| **task_prompt** | Module 2: Early Treatment This module identifies best practices for the ED treatment of TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke. The majority of TIA patients and some patients with minor stroke do not require admission to hospital and should be referred to an urgent TIA/minor stroke unit/TIA clinic/stroke-prevention clinic or comparable ambulatory care setting for rapid diagnostic and medical evaluation. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). Module 2 Recommended Practices  2.1 Glucose management 2.1.1 Hypoglycemia should be corrected immediately 2.1.2 Blood glucose measurement should be repeated if the first random glucose value is &gt; 11 mmol/L 2.2 Body temperature 2.2.1 Temperature should be evaluated as part of routine vital signs every 4 hours for first 48 hours For temperature &gt; 37.5 C: • initiate temperature-reducing measures • investigate potential infection • initiate antipyretic and antimicrobial therapy as required 2.3 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 2.3.1 All patients, whether admitted to hospital or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) 2.4 Management of patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 2.4.1 The following OHTAC recommendations should be followed: • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA with high- risk featuresa or a minor strokeb undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after symptom onset, followed by other stroke-prevention treatments tailored to each patient. With respect to the location of care, OHTAC recommends that: o such immediate care be provided at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinicc o where delays to accessing a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic pose risks to patient health, evaluation (as outlined above) occur at an appropriately resourced ED, and further consideration be given to inpatient evaluation and management for stroke prevention. OHTAC further recommends the establishment of accreditation standards for TIA/minor stroke care to ensure equitable access to appropriate, high-quality care, irrespective of the location of initial presentation o where medical attention has been sought after 48 hours from symptom onset, patients be referred for evaluation at a specialized TIA/minor stroke clinic or alternatively an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd within 24 hours of initial presentation • OHTAC recommends that patients presenting with a TIA without high-risk featuresa undergo a brain CT scan and initiation of antiplatelet therapy (provided this is not contraindicated) as soon as possible and no later than 24 hours after initial presentation, followed by referral to an outpatient clinic with stroke-prevention servicesd for comprehensive evaluation and management within 1 month of symptom onset 2.4.2 Some TIA patients, such as those who present with fluctuating or crescendo hemibodye motor weakness, sensory loss, or speech difficulty, should be evaluated in the ED to be considered for admission to hospital 2.4.3 Patients with TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke who are not on an antiplatelet agent at the time of presentation should be started on antiplatelet therapy immediately with 1 of the following after brain imaging has excluded intracranial hemorrhage: • ASA 160 mg loading dose, followed by enteric coated ASA (81– 325 mg) daily. Most patients should be on a maintenance dose of 81 mg/day • clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose, followed by 75 mg/day • extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg/ASA 25 mg bid (load with ASA 160 mg first) 2.4.4 Rectal or gastric ASA should be offered as necessary, such as for patients who fail swallowing screening 2.5–2.8 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; Australia, Australian Clinical analysis; ED, emergency department; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OHTAC, Ontario Health Technology Advisory Committee; NHS/NICE, National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. aSymptoms consistent with a hemispheric event, including sudden hemiparesis, speech difficulties, or monocular vision loss, and/or known high risk conditions associated with stroke, including atrial fibrillation (especially if inadequately anticoagulated) or known carotid artery atherosclerosis with &gt; 50% stenosis (narrowing) on the side consistent with the hemispheric event. bPatients with very mild persistent symptoms or no residual symptoms but with a small asymptomatic infarct (stroke) on imaging cA clinic with stroke expertise and the resources to conduct all necessary investigations in 1 place to initiate rapid treatment, including brain and vascular imaging, heart monitoring, and laboratory tests. dFor example, a provincial stroke-prevention clinic or community neurology/internal medicine clinic with a stroke-prevention focus. eMotor weakness may be in 1 body segment (face, arm, or leg), but sensory loss must involve at least 2 contiguous segments (face/arm or arm/leg) on 1 side of the body to be considered highest risk. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 2 Implementation Considerations General considerations • Standardized priority protocols should be established for all suspected stroke patients to receive treatment as soon as possible and be admitted to a stroke unit within the first few hours after presenting to an ED • Hospitals should have ready access to rectal ASA Abbreviations: ASA, acetylsalicylic acid; ED, emergency department. |
| **with_task_specify** | False |
| **memory** | current memory not loaded |
| **model_type** | ModelType.GPT_4o1 |
